Award.AwardTitle: Cognitive Functions of the Postrhinal Cortex
Award.AbstractNarration: Recollection of the environment (or context) in which real-life events occur is a hallmark of everyday memory. Yet, our understanding of how and where context is represented and how such representations interact with other aspects of learning and memory processes is incomplete. The proposed studies will employ multidisciplinary approaches in an animal model to understand how the brain acquires, encodes, and processes information about the environment. These studies specifically address the cognitive functions of the rodent postrhinal cortex, which exhibits strong connectional homology with the primate parahippocampal cortex. The primary objective is to delineate the role of the postrhinal cortex in contextual learning. Prior studies from the investigator's laboratory showed that this region is necessary for contextual fear conditioning and that the contribution to contextual learning extends to at least 100 days. The specific aims address three hypotheses: The postrhinal cortex is involved in the encoding of perceptual information that forms contextual representations; the postrhinal contribution extends to all forms of contextual learning; and, the postrhinal and perirhinal cortices make different contributions to contextual learning. Accomplishing these research aims will provide highly novel information about the role of the postrhinal cortex in cognition. This information will be available to guide further investigations of the primate parahippocampal functions. An additional goal of this project is to enhance research experiences of undergraduates belonging to groups that are underrepresented in neuroscience. During each summer of the award, the investigator will teach a behavioral neuroscience laboratory course for Brown University undergraduates and undergraduates from Tougaloo College. Tougaloo College is a private, historically black, church-related college in Jackson, Mississippi, which has strong biology programs, but limited course work in behavioral neuroscience research. The goal is to use the laboratory course as a small early identification program for behavioral neuroscience graduate study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recollection of the environmental context in which real-life events occur is a hallmark of episodic memory. Yet, our understanding of how and where context is represented and how such representations interact with other aspects of learning and memory processes is incomplete.  This NSF award employed multidisciplinary approaches in an animal model to understand how the brain acquires, encodes, and processes information about the environmental context. We specifically addressed the cognitive functions of postrhinal cortex, which exhibits strong connectional homology with the human parahippocampal cortex. During this award period be built substantially on the neuroanatomical work that provides the basis for establishing connectional homology of these structures across the primate and rodent brains. We described the outputs of the perirhinal, postrhinal, and entorhinal cortices to other cortical regions. We also described the connections of the the perirhinal, postrhinal, and entorhinal cortices with the hippocampus and subicular complex.

During this award, we had the idea that projecting images to the floor of an exploratory maze from underneath might provide an excellent way to examine the interactions between postrhinal and related cortices when the environment changes. This overcomes a limitation of rodent models of contextual information processing in that behavioral tasks tend to be rodent centric and difficult to generalize to primates. We devised a new approach to studying rodent visual information processing that allows us to devise tasks that have excellent face validity with primate and human tasks. We constructed and tested a new apparatus for examining visuospatial information processing in the rat. The Floor Projection Maze is essentially a table in which a rear projection screen forms the table top. This allows for rear projection of any type of two-dimensional image to the floor of the maze from below by an ultra-short throw projector. Any shaped behavioral apparatus can be placed on top of the table. The maze can be interfaced with three computers for tracking, electrophysiological data acquisition, and behavioral control.  We also have adapted the apparatuses for use with optogenetics.

We hypothesized that the parahippocampal/postrhinal cortex serves to encode context, in part, by forming representations that link objects to places. To test this hypothesis, we recorded postrhinal neurons and local field potentials in rats trained on a two-choice, visual discrimination task designed for the Floor Projection Maze. Many postrhinal neurons signaled object-location conjunctions. As we had predicted.  Suprisingly, many postrhinal neurons were phase locked to brain oscillations in the theta frequency band. Theta oscillations are implicated in learning and memory.  Our provide evidence that postrhinal cortex encodes representations that link objects to places and suggest postrhinal theta modulation extends to cognitive as well as spatial functions.

Another goal of the award was to increase numbers of underrepresented individuals in neuroscience. During the tenure of the award I established a connection with. Tougaloo College, a private, historically black, church-related college in Jackson, Mississippi. Currently Tougaloo College has strong biology programs, but there was limited course work in behavioral neuroscience research. My goal was to involve Tougaloo students in behavioral neuroscience research. Five students joined the lab across the years of the award. All went on to medical school or graduate school.
